fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The locality requirement for a ringed space is to guarantee that the sections behave like functions valued in some field.

It is impossible in general to discuss the vanishing region of a section f \in {\Gamma}(U, {\mathscr{O}}). For instance, the germs of continuous functions are non-zero on their support, which is the closure of the non-vanishing region. In algebraic geometry, such an overspill destroys most valuable information. We can talk about the maximal region on which the section is invertible, but this is different from being non-zero if sections donâ€™t behave like functions. fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Value of section at a point

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a locally ringed space and a section f \in {\Gamma}(U, {\mathscr{O}}), the germ of f at a point is an element of a local ring. The image of this element in the residue field, i.e. the quotient by the unique maximal ideal is called the value of this section at this point.
Given a ringed space, i.e. a space X with a sheaf of rings {\mathscr{O}}, it is said to be locally ringed iff the following conditions hold.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose f + g \in {\Gamma}(U, {\mathscr{O}}) is invertible, then we can cover U with two open sets such that f and g are invertible when restricted respectively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This can be unified as one condition: If a finite sum in {\Gamma}(U, {\mathscr{O}}) is invertible, then each summand is invertible when restricted to an open, which jointly covers U.
A ringed space is a space equipped with a sheaf of rings, called the structure sheaf.
